text: I'm at the count I'm in Hong Kong at the
air New Guinea counter trying to check
in for my flight I have the reservation
of my flight on my phone and I'm trying
to show it to the woman behind the
counter who's asking me how did I make
my reservation I'm trying to explain to
her that all the information you need to
print out my boarding pass is on this
phone and she's looking at me like I'm a
crazy person because she doesn't get it
and we talk in circles for a while
and then she says can you please step
aside so she can help the other
passengers so I step aside and I watch
as she helps the other passengers and I
watch as they board the plane and I
watch as the plane pulls away from the
gate without me I'm supposed to be in
Papua New Guinea I'm joining an
expedition team where we're going to do
a comprehensive biodiversity survey of
the flora and fauna of the country from
the belt from the bottom of the Bismarck
sea to the top of Mount Willem and it's
a team that the expedition's been
organized by Philippe Boucher's
scientists from the Paris Museum of
Natural History I like to call him PBE
kind of like peanut butter because if
you're not an expedition he's very
essential to have with you there are
about a hundred and fifty scientists
from 20 different countries and we're
all gathered in Papua New Guinea we were
sponsored by several foundations the
National Science Foundation the Monaco
Foundation a lot of people have given us
a lot of money to go to Papua New Guinea
and do this survey and my plane has just
taken off so I go back to the counter
and I asked the woman what time is the
next flight to Papua New Guinea and she
says next week Air New Guinea is the
only airline that services the island
nation and there's a direct flight from
Hong Kong just once a week so I was kind
of stuck after a series of airline
shenanigans no one should ever ever
endure I finally get to Papua New Guinea
and my first flight takes me to Port
Moresby and the second flight takes me
to manang where we're based for our
field
or port moresby Madang are very
different so Port Moresby is the capital
and when you're there you see men you
see men everywhere there are almost no
women to be seen so you the Papua New
Guinea men look like Australian
Aborigines and they're mixed in with
businessmen Westerners and Chinese
businessmen and miners who've come to
Papua New Guinea to invest in the
natural resources Madang is very
different in mundane you see families so
it's a more rural and it's a community
of fishers and farmers and that's where
we're based when I finally get to manang
because I'm delayed everyone's out in
the field and so they send a driver to
pick me up in a pickup truck and I'm
chatting with the driver he's local and
he's telling me that I'm gonna love love
Papua New Guinea and I said okay great
and then he goes Papua New Guinea is a
country of yesterday and tomorrow so
everyone has his cell phone
but not everyone has a toilet so they've
kind of leapfrog there were some of the
important things okay so and I think
about this and I realize our hour
getting here sort of had some of those
dual elements in it so every time you go
on an expedition you have to ask
permission of the country you're
visiting to go there and collect samples
from the governments so in addition to
getting permission from the Papua New
Guinea government because parts of the
country are still under tribal rule we
also had to go and talk to the tribal
leaders because they're landowners and
we have to get permission to swim in the
seas near their islands and to harbor
our boats near their islands and they
graciously agreed so 150 scientists are
now invading Papua New Guinea the first
day and we're all excited to go to Papua
New Guinea because it's the tip of the
biodiversity hotspot but we call the
Coral Triangle and you see creatures
there that are very similar to what you
see in the Philippines and what you see
in the Solomon Islands and the survey
that we're going to do this
comprehensive survey of the medina
harbour hadn't been done since the 1970s
so we're all excited because we think
we're going to find all
these new species and we can describe
all of these new organisms new fish new
snails new new crabs so we're very
excited to go on this expedition and the
first day that I go out with the team
there's a group of local students who
are staring at me and I'm not quite sure
why they're staring at me so I I go to
peewee and he says well they're not sure
what to make of you because you're one
of us but but you look like them so
they're not very many people of color in
the expedition actually a lot of the
expedition's that come to Papua New
Guinea
don't have a lot of people that look
like Papua New Guineans with them so the
kids are sort of confused by what to do
with me cuz I look like them but I'm
leading a team and I'm this girl from
Brooklyn you know with curly hair and
brown skin and and so I'm sort of this
strange vision for them it's kind of
like a limited edition bubble fad all
I'm saying should they play with me or
keep me on the shelf in a box they
didn't know what to do so they decided
to play with me so over the next couple
of weeks the students work with us as we
go out and collect samples and so we're
snorkeling or diving beachcombing
and then we're sorting out creatures in
two different categories the day starts
at around 6 a.m. and ends at around 11
p.m. and we work in shifts in the
morning a team goes out into the field
to collect samples they come back around
lunch they swap with a team who's been
there in sorting the samples from the
day before in two different categories
and then that team goes out till dinner
and they come back and then swap with
another team that goes out to do night
diving so I'm here in Papua New Guinea
because I work with predatory marine
snails that feed on fish worms and other
snails I like to call them killer snails
and so our Achilles snails they are
nocturnal and they come out at night and
so we usually get our best haul from
night diving so we're in our circuit of
you know snorkeling diving beach combing
sorting specimens and we get an email
one
that the Prince of Monaco wants to come
and join our expedition and I'm like so
I know we have funding from the Monaco
foundation but it doesn't dawn on me
that it's the prince albert ii like a
live living person of monaco who's gonna
come and spend three days with us
because he wants to see what his royal
dollars are paying for so i immediately
go to google cuz i had no idea who this
guy was and and find out that he's sort
of like a playboy and his mom was Grace
Kelly and all these other fun facts
about him he's actually very nice so
we're all excited cuz we're gonna have
this royal visitor for three days and so
we on the day that the Prince arrives we
plan this big fanfare ceremony as you
should because you're being visited by
royalty so we arranged for the Prince to
meet the tribal leaders and all of the
other dignitaries that are in the matang
area and we have a big reception at
Divine Word University and the hall is
dressed with lights and flowers and
local food and there's a receiving line
and all of us are dressed in our
fieldwork best which which means like
day-old clothes and the prince is very
nice and he goes around our makeshift
lab and I get to tell him about my
research studying the evolutionary
history of these killers nails and
looking at their venom glands for
therapeutic compounds and we show him
our live nails that we've collected and
he looks through the microscope and how
we dissect out the venom gland and
everything seems to be going really
really really great and then after the
reception I somehow was invited to ride
in the princess car with him to dinner
oh girl from Brooklyn royalty from
Monaco we're in the back of an SUV you
know what do we do so I'm trying to make
small talk and so I say to him what do
you think of air in New Guinea it's kind
of a nightmare
right and and he looks at me and he says
Air New Guinea and he looked at me like
I've lost my mind and then I immediately
get it that this is the prince of a
country he had never set foot on air New
Guinea he has his own plane they go
wherever he wants
oh he's never flown commercial air it's
like only the riffraff high commercial
air so much for small talk
everything okay for three days and we
hang out and have a great time and after
the excitement's settled down we go back
to our circuit of snorkeling and diving
and beach combing and sorting specimens
and we get a message a few days after
the Prince leaves from the tribal
leaders that they want to speak with us
so we're not quite sure what they want
to talk about but we go during our time
there for the first three weeks we were
there we've been doing a lot of
community outreach activities so we do
things with school groups and the local
community we invite them to the lab so
they can see what we're doing we show
them the creatures that we were
collecting and so we go to meet with the
tribal leaders and and when we get there
they ask us for more money or they ask
us to give them some money so that we
can continue our expedition and we're
sort of floor and I'm like what so they
think that we're friends of the prince
and they think that we have money and
they want money for us to continue the
expedition and we're of course like know
what's gonna happen here
so to kind of stall for time we asked
them for we asked them to give us a
number and so they give us a number and
we go back to the lab and we do the
conversion and we realize that they're
asking us for half a million dollars
five hundred thousand dollars of course
we don't have that money obviously we
don't have that money we're scientists
and if you know anything about how
scientists are funded our funds coming
you know all the money is written in two
line items and we didn't bring the bribe
the chief - wait and so we're kind of
like oh my god what are we gonna do and
me and we panic a little bit and uhm and
PB is the best to have on expeditions
cuz he's a great negotiator but in this
instance he wasn't the only one that
saved this the local students whom we'd
been working with they come to our
rescue so they go to the tribal leaders
and they plead with them you know Prince
rich scientists poor and they explain to
them that but the work that we're doing
in in Papua New Guinea is really
important because we're putting names to
creatures that haven't been seen before
and that's important for them and their
training and their experience and it's
also important for the country and so
for example when the prince came to
visit us PB had given him a picture of
this crab that we'd found which we
thought was a new species and we named
it after the monocle royal family acts a
Grimaldi and because and it's a
beautiful crab it's red and it has
really white speckles all over its
appendages it's really really gorgeous
and because we had discovered that crab
and we named it after the Prince the
Prince was now gonna be forever tied to
Papua New Guinea and so they explained
to the Chiefs that what the
breakthroughs that we're making and
finding these creatures and naming them
was gonna be really really important for
the island the country and for their
development as a whole and what they did
in making that plea really was kind of
powerful and it speaks to this power of
science culture that has to happen in
order for scientists for science to
advance we all have to believe the data
that is presented to us by other
scientists right and so working with
these students for the past couple of
weeks we sort of developed this inherent
trust that's necessary for science to
happen and they took that trust to the
Chiefs to explain and negotiate them
down and say that we have to be able to
continue this expedition because it's
important
and so the the Chiefs agreed and we were
able to continue the expedition and
we're all very excited because we're
collecting really wonderful things
species diversity it's very very high
almost every day we're finding new
creatures by the end of the expedition
we describe more than thirty new animals
that we observed we'd also found
hundreds and hundreds of things that had
already been described and so everyone's
very excited but we're also sort of it's
it's a mixed bag because we notice that
the intensity and the extent of human
impact on this harbour is massive so
since the 70s the human population in
the medallion harbours have exploded and
even on tiny Isla it's all of those you
can find human people in all of the
islets were inhabited and so this impact
affected the the reefs so the shallow
reefs were still pretty healthy but when
you went very deep
you didn't find such healthy reefs they
were all sort of damaged and we also
found a lot of dwarfism in the specimens
that we collected they were smaller than
they should have been so all in all it
was kind of a great expedition because
we described lots of species but there's
a lot of human impact that was causing
problems so we were we're in a mixed bag
on the last day as we're getting ready
to as I was getting ready to leave the
expedition the students came to me and
they gave me all of these different
gifts they knew these beautiful songs
which are gorgeous and we exchanged
emails and and I noticed that they are
they see me different than then I see
myself so they see in me this girl who
looks like them or the scientist who
looks like them who lasts like them
who's doing research on a global scale
who has colleagues all over the world
and who's having fun and and I realized
that they see their future lives or the
lives that they would like to have and
and to them I'm a role model and that's
really hard and it sort of hits me
because it's not something I want to be
alright I'm signed up for and and so I
sort of leave
Papua New Guinea with with not knowing
how to handle how to carry that weight
of that responsibility and it's
something I I sort of have to think
about so I'll save you the the story of
how I got out of Papua New Guinea but if
you're ever if you're ever flying near
New Guinea print your boarding pass and
drop some water weight in case you have
to fly in the jump seat between the
pilot and the copilot thank you very
much
